metadata.case_name: Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. State of Bombay

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on February 15, 1951, under order dated February 13, 1951, made by District Magistrate, Surat, under Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

Copy of detention order served on petitioner at time of arrest; grounds of detention served same date as required by section 7; specifically mentioned in public interest not to disclose further facts.

Petitioner moved Bombay High Court under Article 226 complaining detention illegal; urged grounds false, vague, fantastic, bad faith; two affidavits filed by State; application dismissed on April 17, 1951.
Case placed before Advisory Board; reported on April 5, 1951, sufficient cause for detention.
Government decided on April 13, 1951, to confirm detention order per affidavit of Venilal Tribhovandas Dehejia, Secretary to Government of Bombay, Home Department.

Confidential letter No. B.D. II/1042-D 11 dated April 28, 1951, from Home Department to District Magistrate, Surat, confirming detention order under section 9; signed by G.K. Kharkar for Secretary; informed to inform detenu and report compliance.
G.K. Kharkar was Assistant Secretary authorised under rule 12 of Rules of Business under Article 166 to sign orders.
Petitioner filed supplementary petition complaining grounds false, vague, lacking particulars; not pressed before Supreme Court.
Petitioner detained in Baroda Central Prison.

legal_issues.text: Whether State Government failed to comply with section 11(1) of Preventive Detention Act by not specifying period of detention continuance at confirmation.
Whether confirmation order not in proper legal form, not expressed in name of Governor as required by Article 166(1) of Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 11(1) requires confirmation order to specify period of detention continuance; omission vitiates order.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Preventive Detention Act, s.11(1); Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab

petitioner_arguments.text: Confirmation order not expressed in name of Governor; confidential communication to District Magistrate not valid order under s.11(1).

respondent_arguments.text: Section 11(1) confers two powers: confirm and continue; no need to specify period in confirmation as detention continues automatically; Act temporary, detention ends with Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Preventive Detention Act, s.11(1); A.K. Gopalan case; S. Krishnan v. State of Madras

respondent_arguments.text: No formal order required under s.11(1), only executive decision; Art.166 directory, not mandatory; omission does not invalidate; decision taken proved by record.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Preventive Detention Act, s.11(1), s.13; Constitution Art.166; J.K. Gas Plant v. King-Emperor

court_reasoning.text: Section 11(1) grammatically confers two powers; confirmation implies continuance automatically; no need to specify period; Act temporary limits duration; indefinite not repugnant due to Act's life.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Specification of period not necessary however desirable.

court_reasoning.text: Executive decision taken suffices; no particular form prescribed by Act; Art.166 directory, non-compliance does not nullify; immunity lost but validity intact.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decision proved on record; no breach of procedure.

court_reasoning.text: Words 'such period as it thinks fit' presuppose decision on period post-Advisory Board but non-specification not nullity in temporary Act; implies till Act expiry.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Omission undesirable but does not vitiate.

court_reasoning.text: Art.166(1) applies to formal expressions affecting outsiders; directory; signed by authorised officer; not nullity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Loses presumption but valid if proved.

court_reasoning.text: Words 'such period' require specification; failure prejudicial, onus on State undischarged; detention illegal.

holdings.text: No necessity under s.11(1) to specify period of detention in confirmation order.
Non-compliance with Art.166(1) does not render executive decision invalid.
Specification of period under s.11(1) obligatory; omission illegalates detention (Mahajan J.).

precedents_cited.relevance: Section 11 permits continuance for period thought fit; temporary Act limits indefinite detention.

precedents_cited.case_name: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Illegal to specify period in initial detention order under s.3.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chakar Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Government may extend detention before expiry of previous period under s.11(1).

precedents_cited.case_name: S. Krishnan v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: S.11(1) valid; discretionary power subject to Act's duration.

precedents_cited.case_name: J.K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co. v. King-Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: Provisions like Art.166 directory, not mandatory.

statutes_cited.name: Preventive Detention Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs detention order, grounds, Advisory Board, confirmation, revocation; no need for period specification in confirmation per majority.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.32 for petition; Art.166 form of executive action directory; Art.22 safeguards for preventive detention.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to revoke includes modify detention order.

outcome.summary: Application under Art.32 for habeas corpus dismissed; detention lawful as procedure under Preventive Detention Act followed; no need to specify period in s.11(1) confirmation; Art.166 directory (majority view).

key_quotes.text: "In my judgment, on a proper construction of section 11(1), a specification of the period of continuation of the detention is not necessary, however desirable one may consider it to be."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Das J. holding on issue of specifying period.

key_quotes.text: "The position, therefore, is that while the Preventive Detention Act requires an executive decision... that Act does not itself prescribe any particular form... Article 166 directs... but an omission to comply... does not render the executive action a nullity."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Das J. on Art.166 and form of confirmation.

key_quotes.text: "I am unable to hold that this omission alone would make the order a nullity which will justify us in releasing the detenu."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Mukherjea J. on non-specification of period.

key_quotes.text: "After considerable thought I have reached the conclusion that the non-determination by Government of the period... operates prejudicially... and makes the detention illegal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Mahajan J. dissenting on period specification.
